journal-title-group.journal-title: BJOG : an international journal of obstetrics and gynaecology

title-group.article-title: Trends and Outcomes for Deliveries with Hypertensive Disorders of Pregnancy from 2000 to 2018: A Repeated Cross-Sectional Study

fn.p: The other authors did not report any potential conflicts of interest.

sec.title: OBJECTIVE:
sec.p: To analyze trends, risk factors, and outcomes related to hypertensive disorders of pregnancy (HDP).

sec.title: POPULATION:
sec.p: Delivery hospitalizations in the 2000–2018 National Inpatient Sample.

sec.title: METHODS:
sec.p: US hospital delivery hospitalizations with HDP were analyzed. Several trends were analyzed including: (i) the proportion of deliveries by year with HDP, (ii) the proportion of deliveries with HDP risk factors, and (iii) adverse outcomes associated with HDP including maternal stroke, acute renal failure, and acute liver injury. Risk ratios were determined using regression models with HDP as the exposure of interest.

sec.title: MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE:
sec.p: Prevalence of HDP, risk factors for HDP, and associated adverse outcomes.

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: Of 73.1 million delivery hospitalizations, 7.7% had an associated diagnosis of HDP. Over the study period, HDP doubled from 6.0% of deliveries in 2000 to 12.0% in 2018. The proportion of deliveries with risk factors for HDP increased from 9.6% in 2000 to 24.6% in 2018. In adjusted models, HDP were associated with increased stroke (aRR (adjusted risk ratio) 15.9, 95% CI 14.8, 17.1), acute renal failure (aRR 13.8, 95% CI 13.5, 14.2), and acute liver injury (aRR 1.2, 95% CI 1.2, 1.3). Among deliveries with HDP acute renal failure and acute liver injury increased. In comparison, stroke decreased.

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: HDP increased in the setting of risk factors for HDP becoming more common while stroke decreased.

sec.title: Tweetable abstract.
sec.p: While hypertensive disorders of pregnancy increased from 2000 to 2018, stroke appears to be decreasing.
